title: Statistical prediction of dielectric single-surface multipactor discharge under mixed field
abstract: A statistical method is used to analyze the evolutions of the important physical values in the dielectric single-surface multipactor discharge process with the number of collisions,such as the number of second emission electron,DC field,deposited power on dielectric,and electron transit time,considering the emission energy and launch angles of the emitted electrons,the phase distribution of the RF field.How angles and reflection coefficients affect the multipactor is also studied.The results show that when a certain tilt dc field is imposed,the smaller the reflection coefficient is,and the longer the delay time of the avalanche breakdown and the greater the number of secondary emission electrons in the steady state are.When the dc field is parallel to the surface of the dielectric plate and the RF field is specified,the higher the electric field amplitude is,the longer the delay time of the avalanche breakdown is and the greater the number of secondary emission electrons in the saturation are,but if the amplitude exceeds a certain value,the multipactor will not occur.When the DC is vertical to the surface of the dielectric plate,the higher the electric field amplitude is,the longer the delay time of the avalanche breakdown is and the smaller the number of the secondary electron in saturation are.Similarly,if the amplitude exceeds a certain value,the multipactor will also not occur.

motivations: Dielectric single-surface multipactor discharge under mixed fields is a complex phenomenon that requires a deeper understanding of its underlying physical processes.
The effects of various parameters, such as emission energy, launch angles, and reflection coefficients, on multipactor discharge need to be investigated.
objectives: Analyze the evolution of key physical values in the dielectric single-surface multipactor discharge process using a statistical method.
Investigate the impact of angles, reflection coefficients, and electric field amplitude on multipactor discharge.
methods: Employ a statistical approach to study the dielectric single-surface multipactor discharge process.
Consider the effects of emission energy, launch angles, phase distribution of the RF field, and reflection coefficients on multipactor discharge.
results: Imposing a tilt DC field with a smaller reflection coefficient can delay avalanche breakdown and increase the number of secondary emission electrons.
The amplitude of the electric field affects the delay time of avalanche breakdown and the number of secondary emission electrons, but excessive amplitude can prevent multipactor discharge.
llama_json.research_subject: Statistical analysis of dielectric single-surface multipactor discharge under mixed fields

motivations: Understanding the physical values in the dielectric single-surface multipactor discharge process is crucial for optimizing its performance.
There is a need to study how emission energy, launch angles, and reflection coefficients affect the multipactor discharge.
objectives: Analyze the evolutions of important physical values in the dielectric single-surface multipactor discharge process using a statistical method.
Investigate the effects of the DC field, RF field, and reflection coefficients on the multipactor discharge.
methods: Use a statistical method to analyze the evolutions of physical values in the multipactor discharge process.
Consider the emission energy and launch angles of the emitted electrons, and the phase distribution of the RF field in the analysis.
results: Identified that the smaller the reflection coefficient and the higher the electric field amplitude, the longer the delay time of the avalanche breakdown and the greater the number of secondary emission electrons.
Found that if the amplitude exceeds a certain value, the multipactor discharge will not occur.
openai_json.research_subject: Statistical prediction of dielectric single-surface multipactor discharge under mixed field

motivations: Understanding the physical mechanisms of dielectric single-surface multipactor discharge under mixed fields is crucial for preventing breakdown in high-power microwave devices.
The complex interactions between emission parameters, field configurations, and material properties in multipactor discharge processes require comprehensive statistical analysis.
objectives: Analyze the evolution of key physical parameters in dielectric single-surface multipactor discharge using statistical methods.
Investigate how emission angles, reflection coefficients, and mixed DC/RF field configurations affect multipactor discharge characteristics.
methods: Apply statistical analysis to model the multipactor discharge process considering emission energy, launch angles, and RF field phase distribution.
Examine the effects of different DC field orientations (parallel and perpendicular to the dielectric surface) combined with RF fields.
Analyze the influence of reflection coefficients on discharge parameters.
results: Lower reflection coefficients result in longer avalanche breakdown delay times and higher steady-state secondary emission electron numbers under tilted DC fields.
For parallel DC fields, higher field amplitudes increase both breakdown delay time and saturation electron numbers until a threshold where multipactor ceases.
For perpendicular DC fields, higher amplitudes increase breakdown delay time but decrease saturation electron numbers, with multipactor suppression above certain thresholds.
anthropic_json.research_subject: Statistical analysis of dielectric single-surface multipactor discharge under mixed DC and RF fields
